Description: Upper half of a 'kohl' tube of palm-column form: dark-blue glass body, core built, with yellow and white trailed decorations. The circular opening and the individual elements of the capital are outlined with white threads three of which also encircle the shaft directly below the capital. The lower half of the column was decorated with simple festoons in opaque yellow and white glass. Immediately adjacent to the rim the walls of the cylindrical interior are covered with a single layer of linen which adheres closely to the surface. This is surely the remains of the stopper which was a wad of linen, a common form of stoppering. Another form in common use was a small bunch of rush or papyrus. Incompletely preserved but otherwise in good condition.
Curator's comments: For an example from the Tomb of Kha at Deir el-Medina, see Schiaparelli, 'La tomba intatta dell' architetto Cha', 111, fig. 92. Bibliography: B. Nolte, ‘Die Glasgefässe in Alten Ägypten (Berlin 1968), 144 (under 23).
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2009 13 Feb - 2023 17 Nov, Brighton Museum and Art Gallery, LT Loan (3 year renewable)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
